intro.en:
IsoplotR is an R package for geochronology that was designed to be free, flexible and future-proof. The package was named after but is not based on Ken Ludwig's popular Isoplot add-in to Microsoft Excel. It implements functions for U-Pb, Pb-Pb, 40Ar/39Ar, K-Ca, Rb-Sr, Sm-Nd, Lu-Hf, Re-Os, U-Th-He, fission track and U-series disequilibrium dating as well as detrital geochronology.

This website provides easy to use point-and-click access to IsoplotR's most commonly used functions (see the TUTORIAL for details). Alternatively, the same functions (and more) can also be accessed from the command-line through the IsoplotR package on CRAN and GitHub.
intro.cn:
IsoplotR 是由 Pieter Vermeesch 使用 R 语言编写的开源软件,致敬了 Ken Ludwig 当年编写的 Excel 插件 Isoplot. 本程序支持如下的同位素组 合: U-Pb, Pb-Pb, 40Ar/39Ar, K-Ca, Rb-Sr, Sm-Nd, Lu-Hf, Re-Os, U-Th-He, 裂变径迹(fission track)以及U系列元素 的不平衡定年(U-series disequilibrium dating),还有碎屑锆石的年代学 数据(detrital geochronology).

这个翻译是由CycleUser 编写的. 目的是为中文用户提供一个简单易用的图形界面, 以使用 IsoplotR 所提供的基本功能 (更多简介请点击 这里来访问简单指南 获取更多 信息). 其实这里的图形界面所包含的功能以及更多可定制的功能都可以通过 命令行版本的 IsoplotR 包来实现, 现已托管 在 CRAN.

tutorial-gui.en: 1. <tt>IsoplotR</tt>'s graphical user interface (GUI) has four components: a top bar with selection menus for the various chronometers and plot devices, optional settings and documentation; an input table into which data can be pasted from spreadsheet applications; an output window displaying the graphical or numerical results; and a lower bar to import and export data and results.
tutorial-gui.cn: 1. <tt>IsoplotR</tt>的图形界面有四个主要的控制部分: 顶部菜单可以来选择所使用的同位素组合以及投图的设置选项, 还有帮助文档. 底部的输入和存储菜单, 可以打开本地文件进行数据导入,还可以将做好的图保存下来. 右侧的是投图输出的界面, 生成的图像就在这部分县市. 左侧的是表格化的数据显示界面, 导入的数据就在这里面.

tutorial-alternative-formats.en: 2. Alternative input formats are available through the <tt>Options</tt> menu.
tutorial-alternative-formats.cn: 2. 点击 <tt>Options</tt> 按钮可以调整所用的文档格式.

tutorial-contextual-help.en: 3. Contextual help can be accessed by clicking on any text within the <tt>Options</tt> menu.
tutorial-contextual-help.cn: 3. 在 <tt>Options</tt>菜单内有很多内置的上下文帮助文档对一 些概念做了简要的解释.

tutorial-further-documentation.en: 4. Further documentation is provided under the <tt>Help</tt> menu. This includes information about the input and output parameters, and a brief summary of the theoretical background with essential references.
tutorial-further-documentation.cn: 4. 点击<tt>Help</tt>菜单可以看到详细的文档.其中包括输入输 出的参数,还包含本软件所用的理论基础的概要总结,以及相关的参 考文献出处.

tutorial-saving.en: 5. Data and settings can be saved in a <tt>.json</tt>  database format for future use.
tutorial-saving.cn: 5. 数据以及投图设置等等都可以用<tt>.json</tt> 的格式来保存,这 种保存好的文件还可以随时加载到程序中去.

help-ThU-i2i.en: Use the isochron intercept to estimate the initial <sup>230</sup>Th/<sup>238</sup>U-ratio

UPb-err75.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 207Pb/235U-ratios.

UPb-err68.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 206Pb/238U-ratios.

UPb-err86.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 238U/206Pb-ratios.

UPb-err76.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 207Pb/206Pb-ratios.

UPb-err48.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 204Pb/238U-ratios.

UPb-err47.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 204Pb/207Pb-ratios.

UPb-err46.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 204Pb/206Pb-ratios.

UPb-err82.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 208Pb/232Th-ratios.

UPb-err0806.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 208Pb/206Pb-ratios.

UPb-err3238.en: Analytical uncertainty (12σ%) of the 232Th/238U-ratios.

UPb-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in concordia and radial plots.

UPb-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

UPb-redundancy.en: If <tt>rhoXY</tt>, <tt>rhoXZ</tt> or <tt>rhoYZ</tt> are omitted, then their value will be inferred from the redundancy between the three sets of standard errors (<tt>s[X]</tt>, <tt>s[Y]</tt> and <tt>s[Z]</tt>). This inference assumes that these errors are based on the same number of data points. If some data has been rejected from one ratio but not another, because of isobaric interferences, instrument issues, outlier rejection, or any other reason, then this method will not work.

IsoplotR-version.cn: 这是 IsoplotR/IsoplotRgui GitHub 版本

reference.cn: 如果使用本软件,请引用软件开发者 Pieter Vermeesch 所发表的这篇相关文章:

ages-err-75.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the <sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>235</sup>U-ages.

ages-err-68.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the <sup>206</sup>Pb/<sup>238</sup>U-ages.

ages-err-76.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the <sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>206</sup>Pb-ages.

ages-err-82.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the <sup>208</sup>Pb/<sup>232</sup>Th-ages.

ages-tconc.en: The single-grain concordia age. This is the maximum likelihood intersection between the (Wetherill) concordia line and the (<sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>235</sup>U-<sup>206</sup>Pb/<sup>238</sup>U) error ellipse.

ages-err-tconc.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the single-grain.

ages-pconc.en: The p-value for concordance. Note: it would be unwise to use the p-value value as a concordance filter. Doing so would 'punish' high precision measurements, which are more likely to fail the Chi-square test than low precision measurements. The latter would therefore be 'rewarded' by such a criterion.

ages-se.en: The estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the

ages-se-48_0.en: Estimated uncertainty (standard error) of the initial <sup>234</sup>U/<sup>230</sup>Th-ratio.

ages-corr-t-48_0.en: Correlation coefficient between the <sup>230</sup>Th-<sup>234</sup>U-<sup>238</sup>U age and the initial <sup>234</sup>U/<sup>230</sup>Th-ratio uncertainties.

ArAr-J.en: Irradiation constant and its analytical uncertainty

ArAr-39.en: Amount of <sup>39</sup>Ar in each heating step, which will be normalised to form the X-axis of the age spectrum (optional).

ArAr-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in isochron and radial plots.

ArAr-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

ArAr-redundancy.en: <tt>IsoplotR</tt> uses the redundancy of the three ratios to calculate the correlation between their respective analytical uncertainties.

average-intro.en:
Let t = {t1, ..., tn} be a set of n age estimates determined on different aliquots of the same sample, and let s[t1], ..., s[tn]} be their analytical uncertainties (standard errors). IsoplotR implements two ways to compute the average of these data:
  1. A random effects model with two sources of variance:

    ti ~ N( μ, σ2 = s[ti]2 + ω2 ) (eq. 1a)

    where μ is the mean, σ2 is the total variance and ω is the 'overdispersion'. Equation 1a can be solved for μ and ω by the method of maximum likelihood.
  2. A weighted mean algorithm that assumes that any dispersion between the different aliquots is only due to the analytical uncertainty:

    t = Σ(ti/s[ti]2)/Σ(1/s[ti]2)(eq. 1b)

IsoplotR uses a modified version of Chauvenet's criterion for outlier detection:
  1. Compute the error-weighted mean of the n age determinations ti using their analytical uncertainties s[ti] using one of the aforementioned two approaches.
  2. For each ti, compute the probability pi that that |t-μ|>|ti-μ| for

    t ~ N(0,Ξ2) (eq. 2)

    where Ξ = √s[ti]2+ω2 if the random effects model is used; or Ξ = s[t]√ MSWD if the ordinary weighted mean is used.
  3. Let pj ≡ min(p1,…,pn). If pj<0.05/n, then reject the jth date, reduce n by one (i.e., n → (n-1) and repeat steps 1 through 3 until the surviving dates pass the third step.
If the analytical uncertainties are small compared to the scatter between the dates, then this generalised algorithm reduces to the conventional Chauvenet criterion. If the analytical uncertainties are large and the data do not exhibit any overdispersion, then the heuristic outlier detection method is equivalent to Ludwig (2003)'s 'modified 2-sigma' method.

average-mu-y.en: the width of the 100(1-α)% confidence interval for μ. This is also shown as a grey band on the plot. The uncertainties associated with the random uncertainties are shown in dark grey, whereas the systematic uncertainties (i.e. J-factor and decay constant) are shown in light grey.

average-mu-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD (not reported for random effects models).

average-mswd-x.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) for age homogeneity.  MSWD values >> 1 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

average-mswd-y.en: the Chi-squared p-value for the age homogeneity test. p-values << 0.05 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

average-omega.en: the standard deviation of the true ages after removal of the analytical uncertainties. The dispersion is significantly greater than zero if the MSWD is significantly greater than one. The 100(1-α)% Normal confidence region for the dispersion (e.g., 1.96 × ω if α = 0.05) is shown as a set of dashed lines.

average-omega-u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

average-omega-l.en: width of the lower half of the (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

CAD-intro.en:
Empirical cumulative distribution functions or cumulative age distributions CADs (Vermeesch, 2007) are the most straightforward way to visualise the probability distribution of multiple dates. A CAD is a step function that sets out the rank order of the dates against their numerical value:

CAD(t) = ∑i 1(t < ti)/n (eq. 1)

where 1(*) = 1 if * is true and 1(*) = 0 if * is false. CADs have two desirable properties. First, they do not require any pre-treatment or smoothing of the data. This is not the case for histograms or kernel density estimates. Second, it is easy to superimpose several CADs on the same plot. This facilitates the intercomparison of multiple samples. The interpretation of CADs is straightforward but not very intuitive. The prominence of individual age components is proportional to the steepness of the CAD. This is different from probability density estimates such as histograms, in which such components stand out as peaks. It is arguably easier to identify peaks than inflection points and this probably why CADs are not as widely used as probability density estimates. But the ease of interpretation of density estimates comes at a cost, as they require smoothing and cannot as easily be combined as CADs.

concordia-intro.en: The concordia diagram is a graphical means of assessing the internal consistency of U-Pb data. It sets out the measured <sup>206</sup>Pb/<sup>238</sup>U- and <sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>235</sup>-ratios against each other ('Wetherill' diagram) or, equivalently, the <sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>206</sup>Pb- and <sup>207</sup>Pb/<sup>235</sup>U-ratios ('Tera-Wasserburg' diagram). The space of concordant isotopic compositions is marked by a curve, the 'concordia line'. Isotopic ratio measurements are shown as 100(1-α)% confidence ellipses, where α is set in the <tt>Options</tt> menu.  Concordant samples plot near to, or overlap with, the concordia line.  They represent the pinnacle of geochronological robustness. Samples that plot away from the concordia line but are aligned along a linear trend form an isochron (or 'discordia' line) that can be used to infer the composition of the non-radiogenic ('common') lead or to constrain the timing of prior lead loss.

conc-t.en: the Maximum Likelihood estimate of the age using the algorithm of Ludwig (1998).

conc-t-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

conc-t-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD.

conc-mswd-u.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) for concordance.

conc-mswd-z.en: the Chi-squared p-value for concordance + equivalence.

disc-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

disc-t.en: the Maximum Likelihood least squares estimate of the age or initial Pb-ratio using the algorithm of Ludwig (1998).

disc-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD. (only reported if MSWD > 1)

disc-u.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) for the isochron fit.

disc-v.en: the Chi-squared p-value for the isochron fit.

disc-omega.en: the estimated standard deviation of the assumedly Gaussian geological scatter of the true intercept ages.

disc-omega-u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

disc-omega-l.en: width of the lower half of the (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

detritals-info.en: The detrital ages arranged in columns which may have unequal lengths. Sample names may be provided in the first row. If they are omitted, then please untick the "Sample names on first row?" box in the Options menu.

evolution-info-ThU12.en: The Th-U evolution diagram is a scatter plot that sets out the <sup>234</sup>U/<sup>238</sup>U-activity ratios against the <sup>230</sup>Th/<sup>238</sup>U-activity ratios as error ellipses (drawn at 100[1-α]% confidence level), and displays the initial <sup>234</sup>U/<sup>238</sup>U-activity ratios and ages as a set of intersecting lines. The Th-U evolution diagram has a similar and purpose and appearance as the U-Pb concordia diagram, which also displays compositions and dates simultaneously. An alternative way of doing so is to plot the <sup>234</sup>U/<sup>238</sup>U-ratios against the <sup>230</sup>Th/<sup>234</sup>U-<sup>238</sup>U-ages. In both types of evolution diagrams, <tt>IsoplotR</tt> provides the option to project the raw measurements along the best fitting isochron line and thereby remove the detrital <sup>230</sup>Th-component. This procedure allows a visual assessment of the degree of homogeneity within a dataset, as is quantified by the MSWD.

evolution-info-ThU34.en: The Th-U evolution diagram has a similar and purpose and appearance as the U-Pb concordia diagram, which also displays compositions and dates simultaneously. For igneous datasets, in which <sup>234</sup>U and <sup>238</sup>U are in secular equilibrium, <tt>IsoplotR</tt> produces an (Osmond-style) isochron plot that is decorated with a fanning set of isochrone lines.

evolution-t-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

evolution-t-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD.

evolution-i.en: the initial (234U/238U) excess (230Th/232Th)-ratio obtained by linear regression.

evolution-i-y.en: the 100(1-α)% confidence interval for i using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

evolution-i-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for i with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD (only reported if MSWD > 1).

evolution-mswd-x.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) for the linear fit.  MSWD values >> 1 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

evolution-mswd-y.en: the Chi-squared p-value for the linear fit.  p-values << 0.05 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

evolution-omega.en: the excess ('geological') dispersion of the y-intercept, i.e. the standard deviation of the assumedly Gaussian distribution that describes the true non-radiogenic component.

evolution-omega-u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

evolution-omega-l.en: width of the lower half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

FT-tstand.en: Standard age and its standard error.

FT-zeta.en: Zeta calibration constant and its analytical uncertainty

FT-rho.en: Induced track density in a co-irradiated dosimeter glass and its analytical uncertainty

FT-spot-size.en: The diameter of the LA-ICP-MS laser spot, in μm

FT-U.en: Uranium concentration (in ppm, for both the ζ-calibration and absolute methods), or U/Ca-ratios (for the ζ-calibration method only) measured by LA-ICP-MS

FT-err-U-b.en: of U1, U2, ... . These should exclude any external sources of uncertainty for the calculation of radial plots or weighted means.

FT-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in radial plots.

FT-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

helioplot-t.en: the central age, which is defined as the U-Th-He age corresponding to the weighted mean composition in log(U/He)-log(Th/He) space.

helioplot-t-x.en: the estimated standard deviation of t, estimated by the method of maximum likelihood.

helioplot-t-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

helioplot-t-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD.

helioplot-mswd-x.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) of compositional equivalence for the U-Th-He measurements. MSWD values >> 1 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

helioplot-mswd-y.en: the Chi-squared p-value of equivalence for the geometric mean composition.  p-values << 0.05 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

helioplot-omega.en: the estimated standard deviation of the 'geological scatter' of the U/He, Th/He (and Sm/He) ratios required to explain the overdispersion of the U-Th-(Sm)-He compositions with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

helioplot-omega-u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

helioplot-omega-l.en: width of the lower half of the (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

isochron-intro.en:
Isochrons are an important instrument of high precision, high accuracy geochronology. Given several aliquots from a single sample, they allow the non-radiogenic component of the daughter nuclide to be quantified and separated from the radiogenic component. In its simplest form, the isochron is obtrained by setting out the radiogenic daughter isotope against the radioactive parent isotope, both normalised to a non-radiogenic isotope of the daughter element, and fitting a straight line through these points by least squares regression Nicolaysen (1961). The slope and intercept then yield the radiogenic daughter-parent ratio and the non-radiogenic daughter composition, respectively. IsoplotR offers three ways to fit an isochron:
  1. Model-1: maximum Likelihood regression, using the modified error weighted least squares algorithm of York et al. (2004) Maximum Likelihood formulation of Ludwig and Titterington (1994) . This algorithm takes into account the analytical uncertainties and error correlations, under the assumption that the scatter between the data points is solely caused by the analytical uncertainty. If the assumption is correct, then the MSWD value should be approximately equal to one. If MSWD > 1, then model-1 regression assumes that the analytical uncertainties have been underestimated by a factor √MSWD.
  2. Model-2: ordinary least squares regression, ignoring the analytical uncertainties.
  3. Model-3: maximum likelihood regression with overdispersion. Instead of attributing any overdispersion (MSWD > 1) to underestimated analytical uncertainties, one can also attribute it to the presence of geological uncertainty, which manifests itself as an added (co)variance term.

isochron-t-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

isochron-t-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for t with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD.

isochron-i.en: the initial (207Pb/204Pb) (40Ar/36Ar) (234U/238U) excess (230Th/232Th) isotope-ratio obtained by linear regression.

isochron-i-y.en: the studentised 100(1-α)% confidence interval for u using the appropriate number of degrees of freedom.

isochron-i-z.en: the approximate 100(1-α)% confidence interval for u with overdispersion, calculated as z = y√MSWD (only reported if MSWD > 1).

isochron-mswd-x.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates (MSWD) for the linear fit.  MSWD values >> 1 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

isochron-mswd-y.en: the Chi-squared p-value for the linear fit.  p-values << 0.05 indicate that the ages are overdispersed with respect to the stated analytical uncertainties.

isochron-omega-a.en: the excess ('geological') dispersion of the y-intercept, i.e. the standard deviation of the assumedly Gaussian distribution that describes the true non-radiogenic component.

isochron-omega-b.en: the excess ('geological') dispersion of the concordia intercept age, i.e. the standard deviation of the assumedly Gaussian distribution that describes the variability of the true ages.

isochron-omega-u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

isochron-omega-l.en: width of the lower half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

KCa-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in isochron and radial plots.

KCa-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and  calculations.

KCa-redundancy.en: IsoplotR uses the redundancy of the three ratios to calculate the correlation between their respective analytical uncertainties.

KDE-intro.en:
Histograms smooth data by binning. IsoplotR uses Sturges' Rule (log2[n]+1, where n is the number of data points) as the default number of histogram bins, but this can be changed to any other natural number by the user. Alternatively, kernel density estimates KDEs (Vermeesch, 2012) smooth data by applying a (Gaussian) kernel:

KDE(t) = ∑iN (t | μ=ti, σ=h[t]) (eq. 1)

where N(μ,σ) is the probability of observing a value t under a Normal distribution with mean μ and standard deviation σ. h[t] is the smoothing parameter or 'bandwidth' of the kernel density estimate which may or may not depend on the age t. If h[t] depends on t, then KDE(t) is known as an 'adaptive' KDE. The default bandwidth used by IsoplotR is calculated using the algorithm of Botev et al. (2010) and modulated by the adaptive smoothing approach of Abramson (1982). The rationale behind adaptive kernel density estimation is to use a narrower bandwidth near the peaks of the sampling distribution (where the ordered dates are closely spaced in time), and a wider bandwidth in the distribution's sparsely sampled troughs. Thus, the resolution of the density estimate is optimised according to data availability. Kernel density estimates are not to be confused with Isoplot's 'probability density plots' (PDPs). The mathematical definition of a PDP closely resembles that of the KDE, the only difference being the substitution of the bandwidth h[t] by the analytical uncertainty s[ti] in Equation 1. This similarity in appearance and definition is the source of much confusion. PDPs do not stand up to further statistical scrutiny (see counter-examples provided by Vermeesch, 2012), and are not implemented in IsoplotR.

LuHf-err-Lu.en: Analytical uncertainty of the Lu concentration, in ppm.

LuHf-err-Hf.en: Analytical uncertainty of the Hf concentration, in ppm.

LuHf-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in isochron and radial plots.

LuHf-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

LuHf-redundancy.en: IsoplotR uses these data to calculate the 176Lu/177Hf-ratios and the correlation between the 176Hf/177Hf- and the 176Lu/177Hf-uncertainties.

MDS-intro.en:
Multidimensional Scaling (MDS) is a dimension-reducting technique that takes a matrix of pairwise 'dissimilarities' between objects (e.g., detrital age distributions) as input and produces a configuration of two (or higher-) coordinates as output, so that the Euclidean distance between these coordinates approximates the dissimilarities of the input matrix. Thus, an MDS-configuration serves as a 'map' in which similar samples cluster closely together and dissimilar samples plot far apart. In the context of detrital geochronology, the dissimilarity between samples is given by the statistical distance between age distributions. There are many ways to define this statistical distance. IsoplotR uses the Kolmogorov-Smirnov (KS) statistic for this purpose due to its simplicity and the fact that it behaves like a true distance in the mathematical sense of the word (Vermeesch, 2013, 2018). The KS-distance is closely related to the CAD-plot. It is given by the maximum vertical distance between two CAD step functions. Thus, the KS-distance takes on values between zero (perfect match between two age distributions) and one (no overlap between two distributions). Calculating the KS-distance between samples two at a time populates a symmetric dissimilarity matrix with positive values and a zero diagonal. IsoplotR implements two algorithms to convert this matrix into a configuration. The first ('classical' MDS) approach uses a sequence of basic matrix manipulations to achieve a linear fit between the KS-distances and the fittted distances on the MDS configuration. The second, more sophisticated ('nonmetric' MDS) approach subjects the input distances to a transformation f prior to fitting a configuration:

δi,j = f(KSi,j)

where KSi,j is the KS-distance between samples i and j (for 1 ≤ i ≠ j ≤ n) and δi,j is the 'disparity'. Fitting an MDS configuration then involves finding the disparity transformation that maximises the goodness of fit (or minimises the 'stress') between the disparities and the fitted distances. The latter two quantities can also be plotted against each other as a 'Shepard plot'. Additional options and higher order alternatives to these MDS algorithms are provided in a separate R-package called provenance (Vermeesch et al., 2016).

other-radial-t.en: A column of numerical values (e.g. ages)

other-radial-err-t.en: The analytical uncertainty of these values

other-radial-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colour.

other-radial-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted but ignored for central age and mixture modelling calculations; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

other-regression-X.en: A column of numerical values (e.g., isotope ratios)

other-regression-err-X.en: The analytical uncertainty of these values

other-regression-Y.en: A second column of numerical values (e.g., isotope ratios)

other-regression-err-Y.en: The analytical uncertainty of these values

other-regression-rXY.en: The error correlation of X and Y

other-regression-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colour in error ellipses.

other-regression-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted but ignored for the regression analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

other-spectrum-f.en: The fraction of 'stuff' in each column, which will be normalised to form the X-axis of the spectrum

other-spectrum-X.en: Numerical values, which will form the Y-axis of the spectrum

other-spectrum-err-X.en: The analytical uncertainty of these values

other-spectrum-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted but ignored for the plateau calculation; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

other-average-err-X.en: The analytical uncertainty of these values

other-average-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted but ignored for the weighted mean calculation; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

other-omit.en: Optional variable used to ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as '<tt>x</tt>' or '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from the plot.

PbPb-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in isochron and radial plots.

PbPb-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.

radial-intro.en:
Radial plots are bivariate (xi,yi) scatterplots where:

xi = 1∕σ(zi) and yi = (zi - zo)∕&sigma (zi) (for 1 ≤ i ≤ n)

with zi a transformation of some data and σ(zi) the corresponding measurement uncertainty. For example, if zi = log(ti) then σ(zi) = σ(ti)∕ti. zo is a convenient central value such as the weighted mean. The slope of a line connecting the origin (x=0,y=0) of a radial plot with a data point (xi,yi) equals zi, and the horizontal distance along x-axis is a measure if its precision. Thus, the radial plot simultaneously visualises a measurement’s value and precision. No other graphical method achieves this goal with the same elegance (Galbraith, 1988). This makes the radial plot the method of choice for visualising heteroscedastic data, i.e. data with variable measurement uncertainties. Traditional applications in the Earth Sciences are fission track and luminescence dating (e.g., Galbraith, 1990; Galbraith et al., 1999). IsoplotR generalises it to all other geochronometers as well.

radial_t.en:
the central age, which is defined as eμ where μ is the mean of the following log-normal distribution:

ti ~ Norm(μ, s[ti]2 + ω2) (eq. 1)

with s[ti] the standard error of the ith (out of n) measurements, and ω the overdispersion.

radial_x.en: the estimated standard deviation of t, estimated by the method of maximum likelihood.

radial_m.en: the Mean Square of the Weighted Deviates a.k.a. the reduced Chi-squared statistic. MSWD values greater than unity suggest that the dataset under consideration is overdispersed with respect to the analyical uncertainties.

radial_p.en: the p-value of a Chi-square probability for homogeneity. High values of p (>0.05, say) indicate that there is not enough evidence for overdispersion.

radial-omega_u.en: width of the upper half of a (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

radial-omega_l.en: width of the lower half of the (1-α)% confidence interval for ω.

RbSr-redundancy.en: IsoplotR uses these data to calculate the 87Rb/86Sr-ratios and the correlation between the 87Sr/86Sr- and the 87Rb/86Sr-uncertainties.

RbSr-err-Rb.en: Analytical uncertainty of the Rb concentration, in ppm

RbSr-err-Sr.en: Analytical uncertainty of the Sr concentration, in ppm

RbSr-C.en: Optional variable to be used as fill colours in isochron and radial plots.

RbSr-omit.en: Optional variable used to hide or ignore aliquots. Aliquots marked as (lowercase) '<tt>x</tt>' are plotted (except on KDEs and CADs) but ignored for numerical analysis; Aliquots marked as (uppercase) '<tt>X</tt>' are removed from both plots and calculations.
